item.title: The Brexit Edit: Youth Opinion
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
Sorry, boomers – but given that it will be the younger generations who will bear the brunt of a post-Brexit Britain shouldn’t we be listening to them? Three years have passed since the 2016 referendum, and Britain is more divided than ever. MPs remain locked in a bitter stalemate over negotiations with the EU, the […]

The post The Brexit Edit: Youth Opinion appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
Sorry, boomers – but given that it will be the younger generations who will bear the brunt of a post-Brexit Britain shouldn’t we be listening to them?

Three years have passed since the 2016 referendum, and Britain is more divided than ever. MPs remain locked in a bitter stalemate over negotiations with the EU, the rift between Brexiteers and Remainers continues to widen and a General Election looms over Christmas.

The uncertainty, party politics and farcical four Brexit extensions could be comical, if it weren’t responsible for generating great instability at every level of society. Among all the chaos, confusion and the bumping of heads between UK and EU officials, it feels like many voices have been drowned out.

Ultimately, we need a Brexit that does not disenfranchise the British public, and with little to no transparency given on key issues, many feel left in the dark. But more importantly, it is often the concerns of young people that are disregarded. As the inheritors of a post-Brexit Britain, it will fall to the younger generations to deal with the countless list of consequences, felt across the economy, public services, job market, legal system and so on.  So, one cannot help but wonder why young people seem to be excluded from public and political discourse?

We asked Surrey students to share their opinions and concerns regarding Britain’s upcoming split from the EU.

Emma, a final-year Biomedical Sciences student, said the “whole Brexit ordeal” has just felt like a “living nightmare”.

“I disagree with the way Brexit has been handled and how drawn out the process has become. It’s just made me lose faith in British politics … Solid plans and foundations should have been put in place before the vote […] rather than just leaving the public in the dark. I feel like we have no say in anything anymore. I had to stop watching the news, after a while it became depressing”.

Young people are feeling more disillusioned than ever. In September 2018, a report carried out by UK in a Changing Europe found that “more than half of participants felt that they felt their views are not being listened to”, with a further 90% of participants felt that the government “will not be able to deliver a Brexit that will work for future generations”.

 A popular sentiment felt predominately by the young, many who were too young to vote, or have only recently become engaged with politics, is that any democracy worth its salt is allowed to change its mind, especially on an issue as extensive and as complex as Brexit – or at the very least, we should have the opportunity to make a more informed decision and vote again.

What’s more, Brexit is actually damaging to our mental health. A Britain Thinks poll released earlier this year found that 83% of those surveyed were sick of hearing about Brexit, while 64% thought it was damaging their mental health. When asked to describe Brexit, the poll noted a clear deterioration in public opinion: in 2017, it was words such as “confusing” or “uncertain”; now, it is “broken” and “chaos”.

Conor, a second-year Surrey student, had this to say:

“I think it has worsened divides between people – the left and the right, older and younger generations. Overnight two identities were formed, and you had to pick a side. I think it’s created a real rift between people, and the referendum really opened my eyes to how much tension was brewing just under the surface … I don’t see it getting better anytime soon”.

In a time of political stability and uncertainty such as this, it is important to open up dialogue and to come to mutual agreements which are compassionate, humanistic and achievable. Brexit, by nature, is a polarizing subject, but we are not seeing any steps being made to bridge the gap between groups: discourse is often heated and inflammatory, and people are growing tired of headline after headline which look to fearmonger or bewilder.

“Relationships within and between political parties seem to be strained – but looking forward what we need right now is cooperation.”

Sophia, a final-year student from Germany, spoke to me about her concerns as an EU national living in the UK:

“I’ve been studying in the UK since I was 16, and I love British people – but Brexit worries me. Firstly, what will this mean for me staying here? Secondly, will my friends need a visa if they want to visit me in Germany? I also feel like the attitudes surrounding immigrants has changed since Brexit. I’m seeing a lot more hate speech around alone, and I’m concerned that Britain could become a lot more xenophobic.”

A study by the University of Strathclyde into the experiences of Eastern European students across England and Wales found that 77% of pupils had suffered racism, xenophobia or bullying, with nearly half reporting that such behaviour had become more frequent since the referendum.

Many feel that Brexit has somewhat legitimised the xenophobic rhetoric of many right-wing groups, namely UKIP. This was further reinforced by the shift in public discourse surrounding issues such as the EU and immigration.

Practically it seems, regardless of the outcome, Brexit will affect us all. Whilst flights, ferries, trains and any other kind of travel are still guaranteed post-Brexit under international law. It is uncertain what visas may be required and what privileges will be lost; duty free, mobile roaming, health care access, regulations that protect our consumer rights, freedom of movement…

As for EU citizens, it remains equally uncertain, it may be necessary to take out additional visas and healthcare insurance. Those looking to stay in the UK after 30th June 2021 will need to apply before this date to the EU Settlement Scheme get either settled or pre-settled status.

One way or another, Brexit is (probably) happening. This will mean changes, big or small, are on the way. Whilst uncertainty and misinformation sucks… our best defence against Brexit is making sure we keep ourselves informed and updated, and that we make our voices heard – register to vote if you haven’t already!

Text by Declan Purcell (@ardall_)
Photography by Ellie Thompson (@_erthompson)
Videography by Gunjun Bist (@gunjunwanders)
Models: Bojana Simicevic, Leyla Ucar (@leyla_ucarx), Anastasia Koukouraki (@anastasiakouk)
Creative Direction/Production: Natalie Carter (@nat_carts), Amy Parry and Rebecca Cofie (@beccacofie).

The post The Brexit Edit: Youth Opinion appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

item.title: SUBCULTURED X CHEAP MONDAY
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
There are few items in the student wardrobe that can claim they have seen said student through everything, from running around campus during the day to the early morning hours looking for food after a good night out. Jeans would definitely be included in that list. And so the mission is simple: the cooler the […]

The post SUBCULTURED X CHEAP MONDAY appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
There are few items in the student wardrobe that can claim they have seen said student through everything, from running around campus during the day to the early morning hours looking for food after a good night out. Jeans would definitely be included in that list. And so the mission is simple: the cooler the pair of jeans is, the more versatile the styling. Add to that good quality, and you truly have an item that can see you through every hour of your busy student life.

Cheap Monday zeroed in on the importance of good denim and has made a huge mark in the fashion market with its line: clothes that are comfortable, whether loose-fitting or figure-hugging, with an original design that makes a statement effortlessly. Whether it is a pop of neon orange in an all-black outfit, a skull necklace or a logo-bearing pair of jeans, the result is the same: a look that combines functional urban cool – in other words, comfort with a bit of an edge and lots of attitude. Against the backdrop of busy London, with its graffitied alleyways and iconic buildings, the clothes stand out among the crowds due to their vibrant, rebellious feel.

I suppose, then, there is only one thing left to say: thank God, it’s… (Cheap) Monday.

 Orange Jumper – Tap Echologo Knit

Black Sweater – Worth Droop Logo Sweat

Women’s Ripped Jeans – Dona Slash Black Mom Jeans

Men’s Orange Hoodie – Scope Fleece Hood

Orange T-shirt – Screen Tiny Skull Tee

Red Coat – Agent Bomber

Women’s Jeans with Side Panelling – Sound 36 Black Tape Jeans

Grey Beanie – Skull Beanie

Quilted Jacket – Crypto Puffer Vest

Men’s Jeans – Tight Horror Skinny Jeans

Women’s Fleece Jacket – Function Fleece Jacket

Denim Jacket – Legit Denim Jacket

 

A peek at the behind-the-scenes of the shoot:

 

Creative direction by Rebecca Cofie, Setareh Sanjarani and Natalie Carter

Photography by Leeya Mirza

Videography by Ana Maria

Editorial by Alice Papadopoulou

Models: Kyle Birkitt, Mack McCarroll, Talia Cherkez & Silia Marianou

Special thanks to Cheap Monday for collaborating with us.

The post SUBCULTURED X CHEAP MONDAY appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

The post Campus Street Style – 2nd November 2018 appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
On the 2nd November, SUBCULTURED Street Style team walked around campus and shot the best dressed students we could find. Surrey campus street style this week was super diverse from bright, warm  stimulating colours that complimented the weather that day, to more neutral tones and let’s not forget our classic denim-on-denim or stripey trends.

 

Don’t forget to cast your vote for your favourite outfit at the end of this post!

Silia (Business Management, 2nd year) wears: 

Top – Guess

Jacket – Vintage

Jeans – ASOS

Socks – Jewellery Urban

Shoes – Nike

Earrings – Cheap Monday

 

Tony (International Hospitality Management, 3nd year) wears:

Hoodie – Supreme

Trousers – Polo Ralph Lauren

Shoes – Adidas Clima Cool 1

Bag – Eastpak

 

Ireta wears:

Jacket – Vintage Calvin Klein

Hoodie – Urban Outfitters

Jeans – Topshop

Shoes – ASOS

Bag – Zara

Sunglasses – eBay

 

Cecilia (Economics, final year) wears:

Jumpsuit – Misguided

Bag – Fiorellii

Scarf – Burberry

Shoes – Primark

 

Shawn wears:

Jacket – Supreme

T-shirt – Stussy

Trousers & Shoes – Jordan

Bag – Nike

 

Kyle wears:

Jacket – Tommy Hilfiger

T-shirt – Travis Scott merch

Jeans – Zara

Shoes – Nike

Bag – Supreme

Belt – Places+Faces

 

Eliza (International Hospitality Management, 2nd year)

Coat & Bag – Guess

Scarf – LV

Jeans – Armani Exchange

Boots – Michael Kors

 

 

Photography and post-production Anna Irina and Franchesca Di Tella

Scouting and descriptions by Franchesca Di Tella

Editorial by Juliéy Pham.

The post Campus Street Style – 2nd November 2018 appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

item.title: Recreating Vogue Covers: SUBCULTURED Edition
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
When one peruses the magazine ranks, a Vogue cover always stands out. Breath-taking clothes, beautiful models, sleek hair and make-up, amazing photography… all these features blend seamlessly together to create this one snapshot of hundreds of pages of content on arts, culture, fashion and the general zeitgeist. Cover shots carry the duty to represent an […]

The post Recreating Vogue Covers: SUBCULTURED Edition appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
When one peruses the magazine ranks, a Vogue cover always stands out. Breath-taking clothes, beautiful models, sleek hair and make-up, amazing photography… all these features blend seamlessly together to create this one snapshot of hundreds of pages of content on arts, culture, fashion and the general zeitgeist. Cover shots carry the duty to represent an entire issue, to catch the consumers’ eye and to be a significant artistic endeavour. These pictures set a golden standard and the SUBCULTURED photography team have been inspired to recreate some of them, such as the iconic Gold Issue of December 2000. Take a look at some of our favourite covers and our interpretation of them!

British Vogue, The Gold Issue, December 2000, photographed by Nick Knight

British Vogue, July 2004, photographed by Tesh

 

The Gold Issue recreation

Models: Sonia Casado Soriano

Make-up artist: Holly Gibbons

Photographer: Ira Igoshina

The Keira Knightley cover recreation

Model: Saneaah Muhammad

Make-up artist: Onika Khatun

Photographer: Ira Igoshina

 

Text by Alice Vily.

The post Recreating Vogue Covers: SUBCULTURED Edition appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

item.title: Black Students of British Institutions
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
When Yale student Akintunde Ahmad asked Vivian Dang to photograph him and his friends, he intended to showcase the bond of their community. The photos were uploaded to Twitter with the caption: ‘Introducing the # BlackMenOfYaleUniversity’ and soon became a viral sensation. The message crossed the Atlantic and struck a cord with black students in […]

The post Black Students of British Institutions appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
When Yale student Akintunde Ahmad asked Vivian Dang to photograph him and his friends, he intended to showcase the bond of their community. The photos were uploaded to Twitter with the caption: ‘Introducing the # BlackMenOfYaleUniversity’ and soon became a viral sensation.

The message crossed the Atlantic and struck a cord with black students in the University of Cambridge, who posed in similar fashion to show black students in the UK that there is a place for them in Cambridge and they should fight to claim it.

We did not hesitate for a minute to join the ranks and examine the experience of the black community in a range of British universities. From Imperial to Queen Mary to Surrey, we invited students from diverse backgrounds to share their opinions on their university experience, dispel the stereotypes that haunt their high-ranking institutions and discuss how we can move on to ensure there are more black students in higher education, how we can defeat casual racism, what we can do for the future of black students beyond higher education and much more.

So meet the team and stay tuned for more in our upcoming issue!

Alexa Miyoko, Queen Mary University of London, Maths and Economics

Alex Mitcham, Imperial College, Mathematics

Hareef Asunramu, Imperial College, Medicine

Arvin Taylor, Imperial College, Biochemistry and German

Nabil Toure, Imperial College, MSc Economics

Rhoda Manu, Queen Mary University of London, History and French

Joyce Bongardt, Business Management undergraduate, Durham University. Currently at Imperial College studying for an MSc in Strategy Marketing

Kate Nwokorie, University of Lancaster, Law with Politics

Toussaint Gervais, University of Surrey, Physics and Mathematics

 

Project Co-ordination: Rebecca Cofie 
Photography: Setareh Sanjarani 
Words: Vasiliki Papadopoulou 
Post-production: Kendrick Foo.

The post Black Students of British Institutions appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

item.title: Back to School x Cheap Monday
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
According to the fashionista manual, the dawn of autumn signifies little if it is not used as an excuse to freshen up our wardrobe. Apart from the essential knitwear, there is one trademark back-to-uni item that every student needs: denim. Enter Cheap Monday, the uber-cool jeans brand that originated from Stockholm and took the fashion […]

The post Back to School x Cheap Monday appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
According to the fashionista manual, the dawn of autumn signifies little if it is not used as an excuse to freshen up our wardrobe. Apart from the essential knitwear, there is one trademark back-to-uni item that every student needs: denim.

Enter Cheap Monday, the uber-cool jeans brand that originated from Stockholm and took the fashion market by storm with its characteristic skull logo (you might remember a giant skull grinning at you from the window of the flagship store at Carnaby Street). The brand is well-known for its tight-fitted stretch denim ‘Tight’; they are experts in denim and their mission is to offer good quality jeans at affordable prices.

Since 2005 Cheap Monday has branched out into full-scale womenswear and menswear production, as well as offering accessories, jewellery, shoes and sunglasses; in other words, it is perfectly tailored to every need of the uni student. Be it skull-bearing tees, jeans that will last you until graduation, a good pair of dungarees or just statement accessories, Cheap Monday does not disappoint. We, in turn, took the denim to the streets of London and styled some key pieces for the everyday student wardrobe, marking the spot for fall fashion inspiration.

Finally, as fashion consumers become more aware of the toll that fast fashion takes, it is important to single out and shine light on brands with a rigorous Code of Ethics. Cheap Monday follows through in their ambition ‘to be the most relevant and sustainable jeanswear brand on the street’ by ensuring that sustainability guides the whole process of garment production, from designing to manufacturing to transportation, while also subscribing to other important fair trade practices, such as respecting workers’ rights and securing good working conditions.

Seems like all our autumn wardrobe needs is a Swedish update…

 

Shop Cheap Monday here: https://www.cheapmonday.com/gb/

 

 

Creative Direction: Rebecca Cofie

Photography: Setareh Sanjarani

Models: Yvan Zahui, Levent Soruklu, Georgia Moore, Kim Pretorius

Post-Production: Ira Igoshina

Make-Up: Onika Khatun

Brand Partnership Co-ordinator: Olivia Mitchell

Text by Vasiliki Papadopoulou (Alice Vily)

The post Back to School x Cheap Monday appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
